data: A large and well-displayed collection. It begins with three ante-rooms, in the first of which is a rich display of lithics (mainly Neolithic) from the surrounding area. A display of material from Himera (lion-head spouts from the Temple of Victory and red-figure craters being the principle pieces) and a numismatic gallery then follow before the main room which contains Hellenistic and Roman material from Termini Imerese itself. Small finds, sculpture and inscriptions predominate. The museum collection continues upstairs with non-archaeological material (and a single inscription). The courtyard of the building holds a large collection of architectural pieces and inscriptions
Via Marco Tullio Cicerone, 90018 - Termini Imerese (PA)
Three lines of Latin text, contained within double border. Text centred within border, with vacat of significant size below, with evidence of erasure of at least 3 lines of text.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana
Sfameni Gasparro, 1973, I culti orientali in Sicilia
Two lines of fragmentary Latin text. Vacat at top suggests there is not a missing first line.
Bivona (1994) suggests an early imperial date based on the appearance of the letters
Romano, 1829, Antiche iscrizioni inedite appartenenti alla città di Termini Imerese

The inscription is set out as five lines of large monumental Latin letters centred on the upper portion of the epigraphic field on the front face below the moulding (the field is 60W x 85 H). Lines 1 and 4 are larger.
Terminus post quem of 195 CE, the deification of Commodus, and likely belongs to the reign of Septimius Severus
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J. Prag 08-07-2022
Gualtherus, 1624 [1625], Siciliæ obiacentium insular. et Bruttiorum antiquæ tabulæ, cum animadversionib
Manganaro, 1988, La Sicilia da Sesto Pompeo a Diocleziano
Wilson, 1990, Sicily under the Roman Empire: the archaeology of a Roman province, 36 B.C. - A.D. 535
18 lines of Latin text of approximately equal height, with two large hederae in the vacat at the foot of the text.
10th December 196—9th December 197, the fifth year of Septimius Severus' tribunican power.
Six lines of large Latin letters which reduce in height, with a vacat below.
Usually thought either to refer to C.Maesius Titianus, cos. 245 CE, or a likely relative of similar period.
Photo J. Prag, courtesy Museo Civico Baldassare Romano
Fazello, 1558, F. Thomæ Fazelli... de rebus Siculis decades duæ

Honorific for Titianus on the occasion of his assumption of the toga virilis

Eight lines of continuous Latin text. Text fills most of stone, with stone-carver attempting to centre text onto stone. Upright hedera in line 4, with right-facing tail. Two final lines smaller.  Occasional use of interpuncts, in lines 1, 2, 5 and 6: tick-shaped in line 1, and more Y-shaped in subsequent lines. Some sort of interpunct/squiggle in line 8. Representing a pointed tilde (~)
3rd century CE on prosopographical grounds (but difficult to pin down more tightly) - so too Barbieri
honorific for titianus on the occasion of his assumption of the toga virilis
Three lines of Latin letters, centred on the upper part of the front face of the base.
Augustan; normally assumed to honour an original member of the colony, founded in 21 BCE by Augustus
Photo J. Prag, courtesy Museo Civico Civico Baldassare Romano, Termini Imerese
Fiorelli, 1876-, Notizie degli scavi di antichità
Wilson, 1988, Towns of Sicily during the Roman Empire
Three lines of Latin text (despite abrasions, it is likely that there are no missing lines), seemingly set in the middle of the face of the base. Use of one triangular interpunct (line 2).
Likely an early colonist of Thermae Himeraeae, probably Augustan in date (after 21 BCE).
Korhonen,Soraci, 2019, Forme amministrative e scelte linguistiche nelle epigrafi e nelle monete della Sicilia romana
Honours for Procula, Plaetorius, Galeo and Longina

The text appears centered on the stone (uneven right margin, left margin missing). Line 1 is largest, with line 5 also given prominence by larger size than 2-4 and slightly greater spacing. The final three lines are smaller and less regular.
"Un periodo oscillante tra la seconda meta del I sec d.C. ed il II d.C" by letter forms)
Photo J.Prag courtesy Museo Civico di Termini Imerese
L'année épigraphique: revue des publications épigraphiques relatives a l'antiquité romaine., 1888-

Gregori, 2012, Appunti su società ed economia nella Sicilia d'età imperiale
honours for procula, plaetorius, galeo and longina
Honours for an unknown member of the equestrian order
Line 1 is considerably larger than the others, while the spacing of line 5 suggests a clear effort to keep the text centered. The final line consists of widely spaced abbreviations.

The post of governor of Cyprus precedes the transfer of the province to the Senate in 22 BCE, but only provides a terminus post quem for the inscription, which in any case must surely belong after the foundation of the colonia in 21 BCE, but not, therefore, by much.
honours for an unknown member of the equestrian order
Funerary inscription for Gaius Popillius Priscus

Eight lines of Latin text, in centre (but not centred) of stone. Use of triangular interpuncts, although some are faint and indistinct. Interpuncts are not used between every word. Line 1 is notably larger, line 2 reduces, the other lines much smaller.

The dating is contested by Bivona (later C1 CE, post-69) and Manganaro (a date shortly after 310-313 CE), based upon the reading of the word after 'Victoria' in line 4 (Bivona prefers Ticiniana, Manganaro Licininia). The other features of the text would seem to favour a later first rather than a fourth-century date.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana, photo J.Prag 08.07.2022
Manganaro, 1989, Iscrizioni Latine nuove e vecchie della Sicilia
funerary inscription for gaius popillius priscus
11 lines of regular neat wide letters of faily consistent size and spacing, with a regular left margin, almost entirely filling the available field.
Bivona dates to 2nd century CE by lettering
Three lines of large latin letters, centred, filling stone on all three lines. First line is larger.

Four lines of Latin letters, the first line centred, lines 2-4 maintaining a consistent left margin; vacats at top and bottom of the stone. Double guidelines are present above and below lines 2 and 3, but not closely observed (contra Bivona), and seemingly not present for lines 1 and 4.

funerary inscription for publius cestius catullus
Funerary inscription for P. Cestius Catullus

Three lines of Latin text. While line 1 is relatively square and centred on stone, lines 2-3 are off centre. Line 3 drifts upwards. Use of triangular interpuncts between every word, and at the beginning of each line. Beneath these are two upside-down 'V's of different sizes, perhaps stone-carver marks? The first is roughly halfway down the stone, the other is around 4/5 towards the base, and is followed by a more lightly carved E (also upside down); a faint 'C' shape is visible below.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J.Prag 2022-07-08.
funerary inscription for p. cestius catullus

The text is carefully laid out with a bounding guideline around all four sides, and faint traces of guielines to the top and bottom of each line of text. Ligature in line 2 maintains the spacing, with interpuncts between wrods.
first half of the C1 CE
Two lines of Latin letters, seemingly centred on the stone.
Funerary epitaph for Titus Cispius Eros

Two lines of Latin inscription. Despite the break to the right, no text appears to have been lost. Use of comma-shaped interpuncts in line 1, although the very first interpunct in that line is extremely worn but appears to be shaped differently. Long hederae used in line 2 (and below line 2).
funerary epitaph for titus cispius eros
Funerary inscription for a Claud[---] Fort[---]
Three lines of fragmentary Latin text (a fourth line is possible, but the break obscures this; the epigraphic formula suggests three lines only). There is a large vacat on the left side of all text.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J. Prag 2023-07-04.
funerary inscription for a claud[---] fort[---]

Traces are visible of three lines of text, but it is possible, from the spacing, that a fourth line (which would be line 3 of the text) is simply completely lost; the spacing would be tight, however, and more plausibly there is simply a vacat between lines 2 and 3, after the name and prior to the record of age at death, a simple formulation that finds multiple parallels at Termini.
The text is carefully centred (note use of ligature in line 2 to support this?), the final line much smaller.
Two lines of Latin letters, the first larger than the second.
Fragmentary funerary inscription for a member of the gens Coponia
fragmentary funerary inscription for a member of the gens coponia

Three lines of Latin text, centred on the stone, with the header of line 1 filling the upper half of the stone. Interpuncts only used in final line, and do not follow a consistent pattern (first visible interpunct is shaped like a tight comma, second like a diagonal slash, third like a larger comma, final like a downwards slash).
later 2nd century CE (Ferrua on the basis of the letter forms)
Fragments of a funerary(?) inscription recording a member of the gens Cornelia
Two fragmentary lines of large Latin letters.
1st century CE (Bivona on the basis of the lettering)
fragments of a funerary(?) inscription recording a member of the gens cornelia
Four complete lines of Latin text approximately centred
Ferrua dates to the fourth century on the basis of the lettering.

Three slightly irregular and roughly centred lines of Latin letters, with single use of hedera in the middle of the name; the final letters of the cognomen are combined in a mixture of large and small letters, almost monogram-like.
Dated by Bivona between 150 and 250 CE.
Four lines of Latin, approximately centred with slightly inconsistent comma-shaped interpuncts. The lines are not perfectly horizontal or evenly spaced, with slightly irregular letters.
Five lines of Latin letters, roughly centred on stone
Bivona (1994, 184) dates this inscription, as well as ,  and  to between the second-half of the second century CE and early third century CE
Four lines of Latin letters approximately centred on the stone, but not perfectly horizontal. The first two lines are larger, with hedera in line 1, basic interpuncts elsewhere.
Funerary inscription for Lucius Cornificius Philargyrus and Cornificia Nicarin
Four lines of Latin text, all incomplete due to break on left side. Text contained within faint guidelines top and bottom of each line, still visible on stone.

Dentici Buccellato, 1976, Dall'abitato romano all'abitato medievale: Termini Imerese
funerary inscription for lucius cornificius philargyrus and cornificia nicarin
Three line Latin inscription in top half of stone. Text complete. Text almost centred, but shifted slightly to the right. Grey discolouration around letters.
Four lines of Latin text, all incomplete. Line 1 is almost impossible to recover. Block-shaped interpuncts
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo J. Prag 2023-07-05
Dedication of funerary plot for the parents of Cn. Domitius Piso

Only two lines of Latin text are preserved (two more below were previously observed). There is a large vacat (at least 47mm) above line 1, so it seems likely that there is no missing text above. Neat comma-shaped interpunct line 2.
dedication of funerary plot for the parents of cn. domitius piso
Four lines of Latin text, centred on the stone.

Three lines of Latin text maintaining a consistent left margin with initial interpuncts, and irregular right margin. Mixture of different shaped hederae and interpuncts. Most interpuncts are diamond or triangle shaped.
Three lines of Latin letters, seemingly maintaining a consistent left margin, but irregular right margin, with a large vacat after DMS in line 1.
Ferrua dates to the 3rd century CE on the basis of the letter forms.
Six lines of Latin all left justified except for line 3 which is indented.
Epitaph for [-]ettius Faustus, set up by Optatus

Three lines of Latin text, each with missing section on the left. Appears to be centred on stone (on horizontal, but not vertical, axis). Use of triangular interpuncts. The interpunct in line three has chipped to look indistinct from the previous letter.
epitaph for [-]ettius faustus, set up by optatus
Remains of three lines of Latin letters, of which the first much larger than the second and third, with indications that the text was centred on the stone.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana; photo from I.L. Termini
Funerary inscription for M. Granius Dexter erected by his wife Cestia Pulchella
4 lines of Latin letters, centred on the upper half of the stone and fitted tightly to the left and right borders, with large vacat at bottom of stone.
funerary inscription for m. granius dexter erected by his wife cestia pulchella
Three lines of Latin text. Lines 1-2 are centred on the stone, line 3 is at the extreme left of the stone. Use of large 'T' shaped interpuncts.

Three lines of Latin text, line 3 is almost entirely missing. Ill-defined interpuncts used, some triangular. Large vacat at the end of line 3. Abrasions at the beginning of line 2 frustrate precision of comprehension.

Three lines of Latin text, centred on stone. Interpuncts are all slightly different from each other, but shaped (roughly) like horizontal commas, and notably placed at line beginnings and ends as well as between words. Although Bivona (1994) claims that there are traces of guidelines, these are not visible upon autopsy.
Funerary epitaph for Marcus Hortesius Primus
Three lines of Latin text, with triangular interpuncts
Crispi, 1824, Spiegazione di due iscrizioni trovate nella citta di Termini
funerary epitaph for marcus hortesius primus
Funerary inscription for the slave Ianuarius

Three lines of Latin text, with a gap to the left of the text (but not on the right). Clearly inscribed horizontal guidelines to top and bottom of each line, with an incised left and right margin also. Guidelines have the following heights: line 1 (39 mm), line 2 (37 mm), line 3 (35mm). The spaces between the guidelines are not equal, between lines 1 and 2 is a space of between 4-8mm (the gap reduces to the right), and between lines 2 and 3 is a space of between 5-6mm (again reducing at the right). Use of interpuncts consistently between words.
funerary inscription for the slave ianuarius
Three lines of complete Latin text.
Fragment of a later Roman Latin inscription
Remains of two evenly spaced lines of Latin letters; use of double-dot interpuncts.
467 CE or 538 CE, depending on the consular identification (Ferrua)
Ferrua, 1982-1983, Le iscrizioni datate della Sicilia paleocristiana
fragment of a later roman latin inscription
Funerary epitaph of Marcus Iulius Dionysus
Three lines of fairly irregularly cut Latin letters, roughly centered.
Imperial period; other members of the gens occur in 2nd and 3rd century CE
funerary epitaph of marcus iulius dionysus
Funerary plaque for Lesbius and Damophilus
Three lines of Latin text, without much room on sides. Multiple types of interpunct used throughout, although all faint on stone.
funerary plaque for lesbius and damophilus
Four lines of Latin letters, line 1 set far left, lines 2-4 indented with a consistent margin. Only 8mm is preserved below line 4, leaving it uncertain whether the text continued below or not.
Three lines of Latin text (end of line 2 is obscured by break in stone).  Use of roughly triangular interpuncts.
It seems highly likely that the text was centered over two lines, and that elements are missing from the right.

The text may or may not have been centred originally, with lines 2 and 4, containing the personal names, set slightly to the left.
later first or second century CE (lettering and formula)
funerary inscription for marcia, wife of lucius mammius
Three lines of Latin letters, decreasing in size, and probably centred on the stone.
Fragmentary Latin inscription recording two individuals

Two lines of Latin text. Comma shaped interpunct in line 1, with what appears to be a long downward linear interpunct in line 2. Heavily abraded on sides and bottom. Missing text on both left and right.
fragmentary latin inscription recording two individuals
Five lines of fragmentary Latin text. Lacuna on right is approximately 1 character.
Fragmentary funerary plaque for a Nymp[hidia?]
Three lines of fragmentary Latin text.
fragmentary funerary plaque for a nymp[hidia?]

                                databile al I sec.d.C., come suggeriscono anche i due cognomina particolarmente diffusi
                                in questo secolo...'
Two lines of Latin letters, roughly centred.
Imperial, on the basis of form of letters
Three lines of fragmentary Latin text. Large + shaped interpunct in line 1 (Bivona classifies this as a hedera). Bivona's photo shows an interpunct in line 3, in comma shape.
Four lines of complete Latin text. L1 is centered within the stone, whereas lines 2-4 lean towards the right. Interpuncts are inconsistent.
Orsi, 1876-, Notizie degli scavi di antichità
Five lines of Latin text. The beginning of lines 1-2 are damaged, and several letters in line 2 are obscured by chips in the front face.
Three lines of Latin text, not centred, but slightly over to right. Use of hederae in line three.
Funerary epitaph to T. Stat. Hil.

Four lines of Latin text, roughly centred on stone (although line 1 is quite crowded, and it is possible that letter is missing at the end of the line). Interpuncts used only in line 1, but they are irregular in shape from each other. There is a large 'G', inscribed in line 4 at the centre of the stone.
funerary epitaph to t. stat. hil.
Funerary epitaph for L. Tennius Herma

Four lines of Latin text. Lines 1, 3 and 4 are roughly on the same alignment, but line 2 starts significantly further to the left than the others. The use of small and compact hederae on line 4 – the leftmost hedera is a little less clear than that on the right.
funerary epitaph for l. tennius herma
Funerary epitaph for a certain Dionysius and Cn. Terentius Rufus, by the wife of the latter, Vibia Ammia

Five lines of Latin text, although first line is completely obscured. Likely only 1-2 letters are missing on the left side. Use of comma-shaped interpuncts in line 1 and the beginning of line 2, becoming more irregular after the deeply incised, perfectly rounded, dot-shaped interpunct before 'Rufo' at the end of line 2.
funerary epitaph for a certain dionysius and cn. terentius rufus, by the wife of the latter, vibia ammia
Two lines of complete Latin. Use of triangular interpuncts.

Two lines of Latin text, roughly centred on stone, but all contained within top half of the stone. Small dash interpunct is evident in line 1, but possible traces elsewhere. Graffiti squeezed into stone between left edge of stone and start of text, and roughly follows lines of inscription (but far from faithfully).
Bivona (1994, 239) dates to the first half of the 1st century CE based on the missing cognomen.
Fragmentary funerary inscription to Marcus Villius(?)

Three lines of fragmentary Latin text, within chiselled border on left side. Chiselled border ends at top and bottom with large dots. Text appears centred on stone, but impossible to confirm without right edge.
fragmentary funerary inscription to marcus villius(?)
Funerary inscription for Marcus Voluscius Felix
Two lines of Latin text, not centred on stone. Three different interpuncts used: L1 triangular, L2 comma and dash.
funerary inscription for marcus voluscius felix
Two lines of a monumental Latin text. Visible use of guidelines below line and above line 2, with an additional guideline 14mm above line 2. Use of a deep triangular interpunct.

B:'La menzione dell'
                                imperatore Eraclio e dell'indizione suggeriscono una data che puo essere il 611/2 o il
                                626/7 d.C [CIL ad loc]...Ferrua circoscrive la datazione agli anni 612 e 627...'
Ferrua, 1989, Note e giunte alle iscrizioni cristiane antiche della Sicilia
Two lines of fragmentary Latin text. Interpunct in line 2 appears as a rounded bracket. There is a large vacat at the bottom of the stone, indicating that there was likely no third line.
One line of a very fragmentary monumental Latin inscription. Traces of something which may be letters above the fragmentary like, but unlikely.
One line of monumental Latin text. Letters exactly in centre of stone.
Fragment of a single line of two Latin letters.
Five letters of fragmentary Latin text, in one line.
Two lines of a highly fragmentary Latin inscription. Use of seagul shaped interpuncts
Two lines of fragmentary Latin text.
B: 'Il tracciato delle lettere non sembra di eta romana, bensi medievale...
Korhonen, 2001, Osservazioni sul collezionismo epigrafico siciliano
Dedication to Aphrodite by the city magistrates
The text is approximately centred, but with a notable bias to the left; only the final line fills the entire width of the face. The spacing between lines is somewhat irregular.
mid-third to mid-second century BCE on the basis of the lettering.
dedication to aphrodite by the city magistrates
Photo J. Prag, courtesy Museo civico di Termini Imerese
Bovio-Marconi, 1876-, Notizie degli scavi di antichità
Sicca, 1924, Grammatica delle iscrizioni doriche della Sicilia
Manganaro, 1964, Città di Sicilia e santuarii panellenici nel III e II secolo a.c.
Honours for an individual who undertook public building works
The text appears to be laid out with a more or less consistent left margin, vacats to the right.
honours for an individual who undertook public building works
Four lines of fragmentary Greek text.
Brugnone doubts authenticity, on grounds of type of marble, and letter forms (?)
Funerary inscription for a family, including Nemenidas and Cleopatra

Text is divided into two bands. The top band is separated into three columns, with a thin, serifed vertical line on a slight tilt between each column of text. Each column contains three lines of Greek. The bottom band contains three lines of continuous text, although with a vacat in the first line. Large empty vacat at the bottom of the stone.
funerary inscription for a family, including nemenidas and cleopatra
Funerary inscription to Olos Papios Agatharchos
Three lines of Greek text. Text is not aligned with centre of stone, with a more significant vacat on right side of the stone than the left. End of line 1 obscured by damaged top right corner.
funerary inscription to olos papios agatharchos
Three lines of Greek text. Text is left justified.
Funerary inscription for Gaios Seios Ptolemaios
Four lines of Ancient Greek text. Text is contained within right side of tabula ansata. Text is centred on stone.
Noy, 1993, Jewish inscriptions of Western Europe
funerary inscription for gaios seios ptolemaios
Romano, 1854, Antichità inedite di vario genere trovate in Sicilia
Three lines of Greek text, roughly centred on stone. Clear use of inscribed guidelines on top and bottom of each line.

Three lines of Greek text not centred on stone. Line 2 is shifted significantly to right, in comparison with lines 1 and 3. Guidelines are the top and bottom of each line are still evident, but less pronounced than on
Four lines of fragmentary Greek text, with missing text on both sides.
Three lines of Greek text, set within right side of tabula ansata.

Two columns of Greek funerary texts. Right column intact, but left column is almost completely missing. Perhaps a missing epitaph on the right as well. 4 lines of Greek text in each column, text of both columns is roughly in line. The right column has an unusual stepped indentation of the left margin, with each line starting c.1 character further to the right than the last.
Two lines of equal sized latin letters
Imperial, but could also be much later?
Sclafani, 2007, Zeus Soter, Eracle, Leukathea e tre 'sortes' dall'antica Himera
Three lines of complete Latin text. Mixture of different shaped hederae and interpuncts. Most interpuncts are diamond or triangle shaped.
